questions.text: Paralysis of the muscle shown in the figure (shaded in green) causes loss of what movement of thumb?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - Carried out by opponens pollicis - Origin from flexor retinaculum and tubercle of trapezium - Innervated by recurrent branch of median nerve

questions.text: The area behind the stomach shown in the picture given below is constituted by all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - Area shown is the stomach bed - Constituted by left crus of diaphragm, left inferior phrenic vessels, left suprarenal gland, superior pole of left kidney, splenic artery, anterior pancreatic surface, splenic flexure of colon, upper layer of transverse mesocolon

questions.text: A barefoot child steps on the sole of his foot and complaints of numbness of area marked 5 in the figure. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lateral plantar nerve-One of the terminal branches of tibial nerve The nerve of innervation in the areas shown in the figure are: 1. Tibial nerve 2. Saphenous nerve 3. Medial plantar nerve 4. Sural nerve

choices.text: Long head of triceps brachii muscle

questions.text: All of the following structures forms the border of the space depicted by blue margins except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - Boundaries of quadrangular space are; Superiorly:Subscapularis in front,teres minor behind Inferiorly:Teres major Medially:Long head of triceps brachii Laterally:Surgical neck of humerus

questions.text: Identify the structure depicted below which is the most important source of noradrenergic innervations to cerebral cortex:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - collection of neuromelanin containing cells in rostral pons - appears blue-black in the unstained brain tissue - contain norepinephrine, provide the majority of noradrenergic innervations to the forebrain

questions.text: Identify the muscle shown in figure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as 6
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1. Clavicle 2. Coracoid process 3. Coracoclavicular ligament 4. Acromion 5. Acromioclavicular ligament 6. coracoacromial ligament 7. Articular capsule 8. Coracohumeral ligament 9. Glenohumeral ligaments

questions.text: Diagnosis of the following condition is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) - Trendelenburg sign is said to be positive if, when standing on one leg, the pelvis drops on the side opposite to the stance leg to reduce the load by decreasing the lever arm - due to paralysis of Gluteus medius (superior gluteal nerve)

questions.text: The nerve shown in the picture below (in yellow) has its origin from
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) - Great Auricular nerve: provides sensory innervation for the skin over parotid gland and mastoid process, and both surfaces of the outer ear.

questions.text: Given below is the histology of which endocrine gland?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A-Pars anterior B-Pars intermedia C-Pars posterior

questions.text: Identify the muscle shown in figure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Origin Lateral epicondyle of humerus Insertion Lateral surface of olecranon and superior part of posterior surface of ulna Action Assists triceps in extending forearm; stabilizes elbow joint; abducts ulna during pronation Innervation Radial nerve (C7, C8 and T1) (C7, C8, T1) Arterial Supply Middle collateral branch of deep brachial artery; Recurrent interosseous artery

questions.text: Identify the muscle shown in figure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) PRONATOR QUADRATUS Origin Distal 1/4 of anterior surface of ulna Insertion Distal 1/4 of anterior surface of radius Action Pronates forearm; deep fibers bind radius and ulna together Innervation Anterior interosseous nerve from median nerve (C8 and T1) (C8, T1) Arterial Supply Anterior interosseous artery

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the muscle shown in figure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The muscle shown below is Adductor pollicis.It is supplied by deep branch of ulnar nerve

questions.text: Identify the nerve shown in the figure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Musculocutanous nerve is the main nerve of the front of the arm.The muscles supplied are i)coracobrachialis ii)biceps brachii iii)brachialis

questions.text: Which of the following structures doesn’t form a boundary of the anatomical triangle shown in the figure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) - Koch’s triangle is enclosed by the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve, the coronary sinus, and the membraneous part of interatrial septum - It is used as an anatomical landmark for location of the AV node during cardiology procedures such as pacing or ablation - Tendon of Todaro is the tendinous structure connecting the valve of the inferior venacavaostium to the central fibrous body

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the part highlighted below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - Superior angle of scapula lies at the level of T2 vertebra - The root of scapular spine is opposite to the spinous process of T3 vertebra - Inferior angle of scapula lies at the level of T7 vertebra

questions.text: The arrow in the figure points to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) - Foramen lacerum : internal carotid artery, sympathetic plexus - Foramen spinosum: Middle meningeal artery and vein - Foramen rotundum: Maxillary division of trigeminal nerve - Foramen ovale: Mandibular division of trigeminal nerve, vein

questions.text: Which of the following is the action of the muscle depicted in the figure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) - Tensor fascia lata extends from iliac crest to iliotibial tract - innervated by superior gluteal nerve

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with pain in the right hand following a fall. Xray of right elbow reveals the following finding. Which of the following nerve is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - Fracture of medial condyle of humerus is shown in the X-ray - Radial nerve is injured in fracture midshaft of humerus - Supracondylar fracture of humerus damages anterior interosseous nerve commonly

questions.text: Identify the muscle shown in figure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Origin Posterior tubercles of transverse processes of C1 - C4 vertebrae Insertion Superior part of medial border of scapula Action Elevates scapula and tilts its glenoid cavity inferiorly by rotating scapula Innervation Dorsal scapular (C5) and cervical (C3 and C4) nerves (C3, C5, C4) Arterial Supply Dorsal scapular artery

questions.text: Identify the nerve which is most likely paralysed in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - Arise from branches of C5, C6, C7 nerve roots - Supplies serratus anterior muscle and damage to this muscle cause winging of scapula

questions.text: Which muscle among the following is inserted to the bony prominence shown in figure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Piriformis muscle is attached to the apex of the greater trochanter

questions.text: Which muscle originates from the bony prominence shown?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rectus femoris has two heads A) Straight head-from upper half of the anterior inferior iliac spine B) Reflected head-from the groove above the margin of the acetabulum and the capsule of the hip joint It is inserted into the base of patella

questions.text: The ligament highlighted in green represents the degenerated tendon of which muscle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Morphologically the tibial collateral ligament represents the degenerated part of the tendon of the adductor magnus muscle

questions.text: Identify the nerve shown in the cross section of brain(letter B)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - Nucleus located in midbrain - Only nerve that deccusates to opposite side before emerging out of brain - Nerve with longest intra cranial course

questions.text: The diagram represents which ligament complex ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (b)

questions.text: The posterior relation of the structure through which the finger is inserted is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Inferior vena cava - Epiploic foramen (Foramen of winslow) is a vertical slit like opening through which the lesser sac communicates with the greater sac - Situated at the level of T12 - Boundaries: A. Anteriorly: Right free margin of lesser omentum B. Posteriorly: Suprarenal, IVC, T12 vertebra C. Superiorly: caudate lobe of liver D. Inferiorly: 1st part of duodenum and hepatic artery

questions.text: Histological picture of which structure is depicted below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: The main action of the muscle shown in the figure is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lateral rotation of thigh - Obtutatorexternus attaches to the external surface of the obturator membrane, adjacent bone and trochanteric fossa - Laterally rotates femur at the hip joint - Obturator nerve (L3,L4) innervates the muscle

questions.text: The structure 7 corresponds to which vertebral level?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Celiac trunk is at T12-L1 level

questions.text: Which is the tendon present on the ulnar side of the area highlighted in the picture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Extensor pollicislongus - Anatomical Snuff box: A. Bounded radially by tendons of Abductor pollicislongus and Extensor pollicis brevis B. On the ulnar side, Extensor pollicislongus is present C. Scaphoid bone and Radial artery lies on the floor and cephalic vein on the roof

questions.text: Following a fracture of the humerus, an adult patient has a biopsy of the healing area. Identify the predominant type of bone :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Woven bone - When bone is formed quickly, as in healing fracture site, metabolic bone disease, or tumor, the collagen is randomly oriented and is called woven bone - Cancellous, Spongy, Trabecular are all synonymous terms for the thinner network of bone within the cortex

questions.text: Which of the following corresponds to the arrow shown in figure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It transmits nasopalatine nerve and terminal branch of descending palatine artery

questions.text: The anomaly shown in the figure occurs due to the failure of fusion between which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Median nasal processes - Embryological structure that forms the upper lip and nose. - They join to form the intermaxillary segment

questions.text: Von Brunn’s nest in urinary bladder shown below is associated with which of the following:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Normal urothelium - Well defined solid nests of urothelial cells within the lamina propria are termed Von Brunn nests - Most commonly at the region of trigone - Normal histological variant of bladder mucosa

questions.text: The blue arrow in the figure points to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: With respect to submandibular region,which nerve corresponds to that marked by 19 in figure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 1 styloglossus 2 stylopharyngeus 3 glossopharyngeal nerve 4 stylohyoid ligament 5 middle constrictor 6 hypoglossal nerve 7 lingual artery 8 suprahyoid artery 9 submandibular gland 10 hyoglossus 11 hyoid bone 12 sublingual gland 13 geniohyoid 14 submandibular ganglion 15 submandibular duct 16 tongue 17 genioglossus 18 hyoglossus 19 lingual nerve

questions.text: The figure shows the superior view of cerebellum.What structures corresponds to that marked by number 2?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1. Vermis 2. Hemisphere 3. Anterior lobe 4. Primary fissure 5. Posterior lobe

questions.text: Identify the muscle pointed?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: The red arrow in the image points to ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: The arrow in the image points to which lobe of liver?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common position of appendix?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Retrocaecal is the most common position

questions.text: The blue arrow in the image points to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: With respect to floor of fourth ventricle,the alphabet A represents?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: The joints highlighted in blue (2 to 5) belongs to which type:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - Movements of flexion, extension, abduction, adduction with a small amount of rotation

questions.text: Which of the following alphabets corresponds to cerebellar peduncle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A - Optic Tract B - Pons C - Cerebellar peduncle D – Olive E - Pyramid F - Optic Chiasm G - Olfactory tract H - Mammillary body I - Cerebral peduncle J - Cerebellum K - Decussation of pyramids

questions.text: A newborn child has a mass in the midline in umbilical region which was membrane bound as shown in the figure:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) - Due to failure of herniated bowel to return to the abdominal cavity at 10-12 weeks of gestation - Because the bowel normally herniates into the umbilical cord, it is covered by amnion unlike Gastrochisis which has no covering

questions.text: The arrow in the image points towards which structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: The deformity shown in the picture is due to damage to which of the following nerves:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - Clawing of the medial two fingers is shown

questions.text: The area highlighted in red corresponds to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: The characteristic appearance shown below is due to the distension of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - Caput medusae, also known as palm tree sign, is the appearance of distended and engorged paraumbilical veins, which are seen radiating from the umbilicus across the abdomen to join systemic veins. - The name caput medusae (Latin for "head of Medusa") originates from the apparent similarity to Medusa's head, which had venomous snakes in place of hair.

questions.text: A 28-year-old consumes a considerable quantity of alcohol and 'sleeps it off' over the next day. When he awakens, the appearance of hand is shown in the picture below and there is loss of sensation over the dorsum of his hand. What nerve has been injured?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - Wrist drop is shown.This is also known as Saturday night palsy - Lesion of posterior interosseus nerve wont produce any sensory deficit

questions.text: The arrow in the figure points towards which structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Identify the nerve shown below whose overactivity can result in a “scissoring gait”?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) - With scissor gait, there is overactive adduction of thigh - Nerve for the adductor compartment of thigh is Obturator nerve - Femoral nerve supplies Quadriceps muscle which extend the knee - Inferior gluteal nerve supplies Gluteus maximus which is a powerful extensor of thigh

questions.text: The forceps shown in image holds which dural venous sinus(superior view)?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Identify the blood vessel pointed by the arrow?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: What is the root value of the nerve shown below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) - Phrenic nerve arises from the ventral rami of cervical spinal nerves C3-5 - carries sensation from the mediastinal and parietal pleura, the pericardium, and the parietal peritoneum under the diaphragm

questions.text: Identify the muscle pointed
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Identify the disorder depicted below, by comparing with the print of the normal foot shown on the right.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pes planus (Flat foot)

questions.text: Name the abnormality
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Given histology pic is of which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fibro Cartilage Fibrocartilage is the tough, very strong tissue found predominantly in the intervertebral disks and at the insertions of ligaments and tendons; it is similar to other fibrous tissues but contains cartilage ground substance and chondrocytes.

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by dermatome number?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) T10 The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10. The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows: • T7, T8, T9 - supplies skin from the xiphoid process to just above the umbilicus. • T10 - supplies skin around the umbilicus. • T11, T12- supplies skin below the umbilicus upto the suprapubic region. • L1 - supplies skin around the genitalia and upper medial thigh.

questions.text: The arrow in the image denotes which of the following muscles?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Extensor carpi radialis longus The arrow shows extensor carpi radialis longus. It originates from the distal third of the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus and inserts at the second metacarpal (radial side). It is in radial nerve, C6, and C7.

questions.text: The cell marked in the below slide is inhibitory to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Deep nuclei of cerebellum The structure marked in the image is a flask-shaped neuron in the cerebellar cortex, which is a Purkinje cell. It is Inhibitory to deep cerebellar nuclei. Purkinje cells are the flask-shaped cells present in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum. They are evenly spaced and arranged in a single layer between molecular and granular cell layers. The dendrite from each cell passes upward to enter the molecular layer and the axon of each cell passes downwards, crosses the granular cell layer, and terminates on the deep cerebellar nuclei. They are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Circumvallate The given histological image is a section of the tongue showing circumvallate papillae, the largest papillae of the tongue. Circumvallate papillae are large cylindrical structures that are around 8-12 in number, covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man had recently joined a gym to improve his physical health. He attempted to lift a 30 Kg dumbbell but developed sudden pain in his right arm. He came to the casualty with an abnormal bulge over his arm as shown in the image below. Which of the following tendons is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Proximal tendon of biceps The above image shows the Popeye sign, which is seen in the proximal biceps tendon rupture. Popeye sign is seen on flexing the elbow. An extremely prominent bulge of the muscle belly occurs as its unrestrained fibers contract. The proximal biceps tendon makes up 90-97% of all biceps tendon ruptures. In isolation, it has little effect on the upper limb function but produces a characteristic deformity called the Popeye sign.

questions.text: Identify the structure(s) in the following histological image.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Glomerulus The above histology image shows the glomerulus. Glomerulus is a rounded tuft of anastomosing capillaries lined by fenestrated endothelium. Blood enters the tuft through an afferent arteriole and leaves it through an efferent arteriole. It is supported by the mesangium containing mesangial cells and a non-cellular mesangial matrix.

questions.text: What does the area marked X overlie?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 2nd, 3rd, and 4th tracheal cartilage The structure marked X is the isthmus of the thyroid gland. It overlies 2nd, 3rd, and 4th tracheal rings. Isthmus connects the lower parts of both the lobes of the thyroid gland. It is usually present anterior to the 2nd and 3rd tracheal cartilages, but the position may vary according to its size.

choices.text: At the junction of L1 & L2
At the junction of L2 & L3
At the junction of T12 & L1
At the junction of L3 & L4

questions.text: To what level of vertebrae does the marked structure correspond?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) At the junction of L3 & L4 The structure marked in the given image is the umbilicus and it corresponds to the level of the junction between the third and fourth lumbar vertebrae (L3 & L4). However, the skin around the umbilicus is supplied by the thoracic spinal nerve T10 (T10 dermatome).

questions.text: Identify the anatomical structure marked in the given image.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Extensor pollicis longus The marked structure in the given image is extensor pollicis longus. The name “snuffbox” originates from the use of this surface for placing and then sniffing powdered tobacco, or “snuff. Anatomical snuffbox boundaries: Lateral wall: Abductor pollicis longus (APL), Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) Medial wall: Extensor pollicis longus (EPL). Roof: Cephalic vein, Sup. Br of radial nerve Floor: Radial styloid, Scaphoid, Trapezium and 1st Metacarpal.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is palpated in the image shown below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Posterior tibial artery The posterior tibial artery is palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon, as shown in the image. The posterior tibial artery can be felt by keeping the foot relaxed between plantar and dorsiflexion and palpating against the distal tibia behind and below the medial malleolus, approximately one-third of a line connecting the posterior border of the medial malleolus to the calcaneal tendon (Achilles tendon).

choices.text: From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.text: The muscle marked by arrow in the image below is innervated by the:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dorsal scapular nerve The muscle marked in the above image is levator scapulae, which is innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve.

questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below gives rise to which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Falciform ligament The structure marked A is ventral mesentery. The falciform ligament is a derivative of the ventral mesentry.

questions.text: The following finding was noted in the twins that were delivered a couple of hours ago. Identify the condition.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pygopagus The image shows conjoined twins with fusion in the sacral region, which is known as the pygopagus. In monochorionic monoamniotic twinning, incomplete duplication of the embryonic disc can occur. Incomplete separation of the monozygotic twins results in the birth of two infants that are joined or fused together at some part of the body. These twins are known as conjoined twins or Siamese twins.

choices.text: Sensation in the anterior scalp and dorsum of the nose

questions.text: If a tumor compresses the structures passing through the opening marked in the given image, which of the following sensations would be affected?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sensation in the anterior scalp and dorsum of the nose The marked foramen is the superior orbital fissure. If a tumour compresses the structures passing through this foramen, it would impair sensation in the anterior scalp and dorsum of the nose, as this would affect the frontal nerve and nasociliary nerve.

questions.text: What is the outer covering of the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Amnion The diagnosis based on the given image is omphalocele and is covered by the amnion. Omphalocele is a midline abdominal wall defect where the bowel and other solid viscera protrude through the umbilicus. In this condition, the herniated organs are covered by both peritoneum and an amnion. The umbilical cord inserts directly into this sac, which helps in identifying the condition. The defect occurs due to the failure of the physiological hernia to return to the body cavity by the 11th week of gestation.

questions.text: A patient presented with a fracture of the structure marked below following a road traffic accident. Which of the following symptoms will be seen in this is patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anosmia The structure marked in the given image is the cribriform plate of the ethmoid and fracture to the cribriform plate will lead to anosmia as the olfactory nerve fibres pierce through it.

questions.text: Identify the labelled structure:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Internal capsule The labelled structure is the Internal capsule.

questions.text: Identify the liver segment marked in the image below.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) VIII The highlighted liver segment is segment VIII. A horizontal plane known as the portal plane divides the liver where the portal vein bifurcates and becomes horizontal. This divides each section of the liver into superior and inferior segments: - Left lateral section: segment II above and segment III below the portal plane - Left medial section: segment Iva above and segment IVb below the portal plane - Right anterior (or medial) section: segment VIII above and segment V below the portal plane - Right posterior (or lateral) section: segment VII above and segment VI below the portal

questions.text: Blood supply of the marked structure in the given specimen is derived from which of the following artery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Anterior cerebral artery Marked part is fornix Most of medial surface supplied by anterior cerebral artery. Fornix is supplied by anterior cerebral > internal carotid & posterior cerebral artery.
